pageData.text: The heart is the center of the cardiovascular system. It pumps oxygenated blood throughout the body, and deoxygenated blood to the capillaries of the lungs. In this investigation, the student will be guided through the dissection and close examination of an adult mammalian heart.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation -   10 minutes
Activity 1: Dissection of a Mammalian Heart -   40 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation -   10 minutes
Activity 1: Dissection of a Mammalian Heart -   40 minutes

text: Paper towels
70% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or other non-bleach disinfectant
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking digital photos

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Identify external and internal anatomical features of the heart.
Apply anatomical terminology while performing a heart dissection.
Describe the functions of the chambers, valves, and major vessels of the heart.
Distinguish between pulmonary and <button class='glossary-text'>systemic circulation</button>.
Trace the flow of blood through the heart.

pageData.text: At some point in life, most people will experience a “broken heart”. This feeling can occur because of the loss of a loved one or the ending of a relationship. But can we really die of a broken heart? Strong emotions such as depression, anger, and fear are linked to heart disease and can lead to death<sup class=bodySupscript>1</sup>. Although rare, a broken heart can indeed be fatal.

Broken Heart Syndrome, also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, is not well understood. However, it is understood that when extreme depression, anger, and fear are felt, hormones trigger spasms. These hormones can also cause the heart muscles to stop. When this occurs, it appears the person is having a heart attack. Usually, the muscles relax, and blood flow begins again, but in some extremely rare instances there is no improvement1. If you or someone you know is struggling with depression, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) describes programs that can help.

1Can You Die of a Broken Heart? And Other Emotional Questions. (February 12, 2020). the Cleveland Clinic.
https://health.clevelandclinic.org/can-die-broken-heart-emotional-questions/#:~:text=So%20yes%2C%20in%20fact%2C%20you,which%20can%20be%20life%2Dthreatening.

pageData.desc: A man wearing a hooded sweatshirt sitting on a curb with his hands on his head
pageData.altText: A man wearing a hooded sweatshirt sitting on a curb with his hands on his head

pageData.text: The cardiovascular system circulates blood through the body. The heart pumps blood through blood vessels—arteries, capillaries, and veins. As blood flows through these vessels, it  dioxide and waste products from them.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Cardiovascular System

pageData.subTitle: The human heart
pageData.text: The human heart is a muscular pump about the size of a human fist. It has 4 chambers—2 and 2 . It has 4 heart valves. Two are located between the chambers and 2 exit the heart, preventing the backflow of blood.

pageData.altText: cardiac muscle

pageData.text: The heart consists of cardiac muscle, a striated and involuntary muscle. Individual cardiac muscle cells (cardiomyocytes) are connected by intercalated discs that coordinate synchronized muscle contraction.

pageData.subTitle: The 2 circulation loops
pageData.text:
Pulmonary
The right side of the heart pumps oxygen-deficient blood to the lungs where it releases CO2 and becomes oxygenated. This blood then returns to the heart.
Pathway: right atrium → right ventricle → lungs → left atrium

Systemic
The left side of the heart pumps oxygenated blood to body tissues where it delivers O2 and picks up CO2 and other waste products. This deoxygenated blood then travels back to the heart where it begins the pulmonary loop.
Pathway: left atrium → left ventricle → body → right atrium

pageData.subTitle: Blood composition
pageData.text: The human body contains about 5 liters of blood. Blood consists of red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets, and plasma.

Arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to arterioles and then to capillaries. Capillary walls are thin—only a single cell thick—allowing O<sub>2</sub> and nutrients to enter tissues while waste products are removed. Blood then travels through venules and into larger veins that carry it back to the heart.

The body is made up of organ systems, each with a specific role in maintaining life. Each organ system consists of a number of organs that operate collectively to carry out certain body functions. At every level of organization, whether at the cellular, tissue, organ, or organsystem level, each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This concept is known as the . In this activity, a sheep heart will be examined and dissected to understand the relationship between structure (anatomy) and function (physiology).Organ systems do not operate independently, but rather are coordinated for the organism to survive. The interdependence of organ systems needed for –the dynamic equilibrium the body sustains when in good health–must be considered and understood. For example, the heart is part of the circulatory system and is involved in transportation of materials, including nutrients, hormones, and gases, such as oxygen and carbon dioxide, throughout the body.The circulatory system is composed of a network of vessels lined with endothelium, a type of epithelium (covering and lining tissue). The walls of blood vessels may include connective tissue and smooth muscle.

The heart is an expanded region of the circulatory system, so it is not surprising to find that it is made up of tissues very similar to those found in blood vessels. The interior spaces are lined with <button class='glossary-text'>endocardium</button>, endothelial tissue of the heart. Some components, such as the valves, contain connective tissue, and the heart is enclosed in an outer connective tissue layer called the <button class='glossary-text'>epicardium</button>. The walls of the heart are composed mainly of <button class='glossary-text'>cardiac muscle</button>, an involuntary type of striated muscle tissue. The middle, muscular layer of the heart wall is termed the <button class='glossary-text'>myocardium</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 1. The layers of the heart wall.
pageData.altText: Figure 1. The layers of the heart wall.

pageData.text: The mammalian four-chambered heart allows for two cardiovascular pathways: the <button class='glossary-text'>pulmonary circulation</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>systemic circulation</button> (Figure 2). Together, these two pathways carry blood throughout the body while maintaining separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. The pulmonary circulation carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart through the capillaries in the lungs, and then returns oxygenated blood to the heart. The systemic circulation is responsible for providing this oxygenrich blood to the rest of the body and returning it to the heart so it can enter the pulmonary circulation. These two interdependent circulatory loops enable mammals to use oxygen efficiently.

pageData.desc: Figure 2. Detailed diagram of the pulmonary and systemic circulations, showing the pathway of blood flow through the heart and the sites of exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide.
pageData.altText: Figure 2. Detailed diagram of the pulmonary and systemic circulations, showing the pathway of blood flow through the heart and the sites of exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide.

pageData.question: As you use dissection tools to cut through a mammalian heart in this investigation, what is the order of the tissue layers your tools will encounter from outermost to innermost?

options.text: epicardium, myocardium, endocardium
endocardium, epicardium, myocardium
cardiac muscle, connective tissue
vascular tissue, connective tissue, muscle tissue
myocardium, epicardium

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The outermost layer of the heart is the epicardium, the middle layer is the muscular myocardium, and the innermost layer is the endocardium.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the cardiac muscle tissue that makes up the myocardium?

options.text: involuntary, striated muscle
voluntary, smooth muscle
involuntary, smooth muscle
voluntary, skeletal muscle
voluntary, striated muscle

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The myocardium is made up of involuntary muscle, specifically striated muscle tissue.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, the walls of which consist of three tissue layers. The outermost layer is the epicardium made up of connective tissue. The middle layer, which makes up most of the heart wall, consists of striated muscle tissue and is called the myocardium. The innermost layer is the endocardium, an epithelial lining that covers the interior spaces of the heart chambers.

img.alt: Figure 1. The layers of the heart wall.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, the walls of which consist of three tissue layers. The outermost layer is the epicardium made up of connective tissue. The middle layer, which makes up most of the heart wall, consists of striated muscle tissue and is called the myocardium. The innermost layer is the endocardium, an epithelial lining that covers the interior spaces of the heart chambers.

img.alt: Figure 1. The layers of the heart wall.

pageData.text: Heart Structure and FunctionThe mammalian heart (Figure 3) consists of four chambers: two (receiving chambers) and two (powerful pumping chambers). Blood enters the right and left atria and leaves the heart via the right and left ventricles. When the atria contract, they push blood a short distance into the ventricles. From the ventricles, the blood is forced into the arteries and out of the heart. The muscular walls of the ventricles are much thicker than those of the atria; thus, ventricular contraction creates high pressure to send blood a greater distance. The walls of the left ventricle are particularly thick due to its role in propelling the .The is the main vessel conveying oxygenated blood from the heart into the rest of the (see ). The curved region of the aorta near its attachment to the heart is known as the aortic arch. The brachiocephalic trunk (also known as the brachiocephalic ) is a major branch from the aortic arch that splits apart to form the right subclavian artery, supplying the right forelimb, and right common carotid artery, supplying the right side of the head and neck. The left common carotid artery branches from the aortic arch to supply the left side of the head and neck, and the left subclavian artery branches afterward to supply the left forelimb.

pageData.desc: Figure 3. Detailed diagram showing the pathway of blood flow into, through, and out of the heart.
pageData.altText: Figure 3. Detailed diagram showing the pathway of blood flow into, through, and out of the heart.

pageData.question: Based on the principle of complementarity of structure and function, which of the following best describes the ventricles of the mammalian heart?

options.text: The ventricle walls are thick to force blood a greater distance through the body.
The ventricle walls are lined with epithelium to facilitate the diffusion of oxygen and nutrients.
The ventricle walls are thin to prevent blood cells from rupturing as the heart pumps.
The ventricle walls consist of two types of muscle to generate greater blood pressure.
The ventricle walls are the same as the atria walls to facilitate synchronized pumping.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The ventricle walls are thicker than the atria walls because they are responsible for pumping blood a greater distance through the body.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between the atria and ventricles of the mammalian heart?

options.text: The atria receive blood coming to the heart; the ventricles pump blood away from the heart.
The atria pump blood to the lungs; the ventricles pump blood to the rest of the body.
The atria receive blood from the lungs; the ventricles receive blood from the rest of the body.
The atria receive blood from the ventricles; the ventricles pump blood to the brain.
The atria pump blood to the ventricles; the ventricles pump blood to the lungs.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The atria, the two smaller heart chambers superior to the ventricles, receive blood coming to the heart from either the body or the lungs. The ventricles, the two larger heart chambers, pump blood from the heart to lungs and the rest of the body.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The mammalian heart is made up of four chambers: two smaller chambers that receive blood coming to the heart, the right and left atria; and two larger chambers that pump blood away from the heart, the right and left ventricles. The pumping power of the two sets of chambers differs based on their functions. The atria have thinner walls because they only pump blood to the ventricles; the ventricles have thicker walls to pump blood to the lungs and the rest of the body. Notice the difference in wall thickness for each chamber of the heart shown here.

img.alt: A heart with the chambers and major blood vessels of the heart labeled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The mammalian heart is made up of four chambers: two smaller chambers that receive blood coming to the heart, the right and left atria; and two larger chambers that pump blood away from the heart, the right and left ventricles. The pumping power of the two sets of chambers differs based on their functions. The atria have thinner walls because they only pump blood to the ventricles; the ventricles have thicker walls to pump blood to the lungs and the rest of the body. Notice the difference in wall thickness for each chamber of the heart shown here.

img.alt: A heart with the chambers and major blood vessels of the heart labeled.

pageData.text: To understand pulmonary and <button class='glossary-text'>systemic circulation</button> more clearly, the path of the blood must be traced through the heart, as shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>. Deoxygenated blood returning to the heart from the rest of the body enters the right <button class='glossary-text'>atrium</button> via the <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>inferior</button> vena cavae. When the atrial muscle contracts, blood is pushed into the right ventricle. When the right ventricle contracts, blood is forced into the pulmonary trunk, which branches to form the right and left pulmonary arteries. These two arteries carry blood to the lungs. As the blood enters capillary beds in the lungs, carbon dioxide diffuses out of the blood and into air sacs, and oxygen diffuses from the air sacs into the blood. This oxygenated blood returns to the heart through the pulmonary <button class='glossary-text'>veins</button>. This constitutes the <button class='glossary-text'>pulmonary circulation</button>.

The pulmonary veins empty blood into the left atrium, which contracts at the same time as the right atrium. Blood from the left atrium is forced into the left ventricle. As the <button class='glossary-text'>ventricles</button> contract, blood in the left ventricle is forced into the <button class='glossary-text'>aorta</button>. The aorta conveys blood to arteries that branch to transport the oxygen-rich blood through the body. Oxygen is delivered to the various tissues of the body, and deoxygenated blood is conveyed back toward the heart through veins that eventually lead back to the vena cavae. This pathway of blood constitutes the systemic circulation.

These two cardiovascular pathways carry blood simultaneously. The heart chambers contract rhythmically to ensure that blood continues on its proper course. This rhythmic contraction and relaxation of the heart muscle is called the <button class='glossary-text'>cardiac cycle</button>. During this cycle, the atrial walls contract. This contraction forces blood into the relaxed ventricles. As the <button class='glossary-text'>atria</button> relax, the muscular walls of the ventricles contract. Both ventricles then relax, completing the cycle.

pageData.question: Pulmonary and systemic circulation each rely on the flow of blood through the heart. Which of the following best describes the blood in the heart as it facilitates these two cardiovascular pathways?

options.text: The right chambers contain deoxygenated blood; the left chambers contain oxygenated blood.
The right chambers contain oxygenated blood; the left chambers contain deoxygenated blood.
The atria contain deoxygenated blood; the ventricles contain oxygenated blood.
The atria contain oxygenated blood; the ventricles contain deoxygenated blood.
All chambers contain deoxygenated blood during pulmonary circulation; all chambers contain oxygenated blood during systemic circulation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The right atrium and ventricle contain deoxygenated blood received from the body during systemic circulation. The left atrium and ventricle contain oxygenated blood received from the lungs during pulmonary circulation.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the functional differences between pulmonary and systemic circulation?

options.text: Pulmonary circulation oxygenates blood; systemic circulation distributes oxygenated blood.
Pulmonary circulation deoxygenates blood; systemic circulation collects deoxygenated blood.
Pulmonary circulation nourishes the lungs; systemic circulation nourishes the heart.
Pulmonary circulation filters out waste from blood; systemic circulation adds waste to blood.
Pulmonary circulation pumps blood to the body; systemic circulation pumps blood in the heart.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Pulmonary circulation is the circulation of blood between the heart and the lungs that allows deoxygenated blood to become oxygenated. Systemic circulation is the circulation of blood between the heart and the rest of the body so oxygenated blood can be delivered to body tissues and deoxygenated blood can be returned to the heart.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Practice retracing the pathways of pulmonary and systemic circulation. For pulmonary circulation, start at the right atrium and trace the flow of blood back to the heart. For system circulation, start at the left atrium and trace the flow of blood to the upper or lower body and back to the heart.

img.alt: Detailed diagram showing the pathway of blood flow into, through, and out of the heart.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Practice retracing the pathways of pulmonary and systemic circulation. For pulmonary circulation, start at the right atrium and trace the flow of blood back to the heart. For system circulation, start at the left atrium and trace the flow of blood to the upper or lower body and back to the heart.

img.alt: Detailed diagram showing the pathway of blood flow into, through, and out of the heart.

pageData.text: Blood moving from an <button class='glossary-text'>atrium</button> to a ventricle must flow through an <button class='glossary-text'>atrioventricular valve</button>. There are two atrioventricular valves: the <button class='glossary-text'>bicuspid valve</button> (also known as the mitral valve) on the left side of the heart, and the <button class='glossary-text'>tricuspid valve</button> on the right. These valves allow for one-way flow of blood. When the ventricle contracts, the valve prevents blood from being forced back into the atrium. The valves are flaps, or cusps, of connective tissue anchored by strong fibers. These fibers are known as <button class='glossary-text'>chordae tendineae</button>, and prevent the valves from opening during ventricular contraction. The chordae tendinae are anchored by <button class='glossary-text'>papillary muscles</button> found in the walls of the <button class='glossary-text'>ventricles</button>.

When blood is forced from the ventricles, it passes through <button class='glossary-text'>semilunar valves</button>. One semilunar valve, called the <button class='glossary-text'>aortic valve</button>, is located where the <button class='glossary-text'>aorta</button> leaves the left ventricle; the other, called the <button class='glossary-text'>pulmonary valve</button>, can be found where the pulmonary trunk leaves the right ventricle. Once the ventricles have relaxed, the semilunar valves keep blood from moving back into the ventricles.

Because the heart is a continuously working muscle, it needs a constant supply of nutrients and oxygen. However, oxygen in the blood does not have time to diffuse across the thick endothelial lining of the chambers. The heart, therefore, has its own series of blood vessels that provide nourishment. The branches from the aorta as it leaves the heart. It then branches into arteries that carry oxygenated blood to the capillary beds within the heart walls. return oxygen-poor blood from the walls of the heart to the . The cardiac veins return blood to the coronary sinus, which opens into the right atrium.

pageData.desc: Figure 4. A heart with the atrioventricular valves labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 4. A heart with the atrioventricular valves labeled.

pageData.text: Anatomists and health care providers use a very specific terminology that enables them to precisely communicate their work. Directional anatomical terms are used for describing the relative positions of different body structures or to provide instructions for incisions. Directional anatomical terms (<button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button> and Figure 5) are used in this and most other dissection guides to describe the relative positions of body structures. Therefore, learning these terms is essential for the understanding and study of anatomy.

pageData.desc: Figure 5. Drawing showing the midsagittal, transverse,and frontal anatomical planes on a quadruped, represented by a cat, and a biped, represented by a human.
pageData.altText: Figure 5. Drawing showing the midsagittal, transverse,and frontal anatomical planes on a quadruped, represented by a cat, and a biped, represented by a human.

tableData.text: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with ventral
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with dorsal
Toward the back or spine; synonymous with posterior
Toward the belly or abdomen; synonymous with anterior
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross-sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.question: If a patient were to have a heart defect in which the chordae tendinae were structurally impaired, which of the following symptoms would be most likely to occur?

options.text: Blood would regurgitate back into the atria upon ventricular contraction.
Blood would flow in one direction through the heart.
Oxygenated and deoxygenated blood would mix in the heart.
Blood would not be able to reach the body’s extremities.
Blood would diffuse across the endothelial lining into the heart walls.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The chordae tendinae are the strong fibers which anchor the valves of the heart and prevent them from opening when the ventricles contract. Weakened fibers could cause the valves to partially open during ventricular contraction, sending some blood back into the atria.

pageData.question: The tricuspid valve separates which two structures?

options.text: the right atrium and right ventricle
the right ventricle and pulmonary artery
the pulmonary artery and aorta
the left atrium and left ventricle
the left ventricle and right ventricle

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The tricuspid valve separates the right atrium from the right ventricle and prevents blood from flowing backwards into the right atrium when the right ventricle contracts.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: As blood moves from an atrium to a ventricle, it passes through an atrioventricular valve. These valves are flaps, or cusps, of connective tissue anchored by strong fibers known as chordae tendinae, which in turn are anchored by papillary muscles in the ventricle walls. The chordae tendinae keep the valve closed when the ventricle contracts, preventing blood from flowing backward into the atrium. There are two atrioventricular valves: the bicuspid, or mitral, valve on the left side of the heart, and the tricuspid valve on the right side.

img.alt: Figure 4. A heart with the atrioventricular valves labeled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: As blood moves from an atrium to a ventricle, it passes through an atrioventricular valve. These valves are flaps, or cusps, of connective tissue anchored by strong fibers known as chordae tendinae, which in turn are anchored by papillary muscles in the ventricle walls. The chordae tendinae keep the valve closed when the ventricle contracts, preventing blood from flowing backward into the atrium. There are two atrioventricular valves: the bicuspid, or mitral, valve on the left side of the heart, and the tricuspid valve on the right side.

img.alt: Figure 4. A heart with the atrioventricular valves labeled.

This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety glasses or goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or workspace thoroughly before and after the dissection, using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).

pageData.text: Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as disinfectant.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.

Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:
  • Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
  • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
  • Always use a sharp blade.
  • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
  • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
  • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.text: Carolina’s Perfect Solution®Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® specimens does not require specialized ventilation.

Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Do not ingest specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Storage of SpecimensIf it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

Isopropyl alcohol is a mild skin irritant.
Isopropyl alcohol is an environmental hazard.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate handling of a scalpel?

options.text: Wanda uses a scalpel to open packaging containing lab kit materials.
Bethany uses a new scalpel after her old scalpel blade becomes nicked.
Cora holds the specimen superior to the scalpel’s movement during an incision.
Diana makes sure the scalpel blade is sharp before starting the dissection.
Pamela makes incisions with the scalpel using a downward motion.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes proper storage of the mammalian heart specimen between work periods?

options.text: The specimen is placed in its storage bag with as little air as possible.
The specimen is placed on the foam tray in the refrigerator.
The specimen is placed in a jar with as much of the original solution as possible.
The specimen is placed on the absorbent pad at room temperature to dry out.
The specimen is placed in an opaque container.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review the dissection instructions and the glossary at the end of this investigation.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area. Put on your PPE: safety glasses, gloves, and lab apron, and keep them on during the dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay the scalpel, forceps, probe, and hand lens (if available) on the pad.
Inspect the scalpel. Do not use the scalpel if it is bent, nicked, or damaged.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so it is easily viewed.

You will begin your dissection of the preserved mammalian heart by examining its external structures. Then, you will open the heart along its <button class='glossary-text'>frontal plane</button> to examine its internal structures.

typeBefore.title: Click to view a video showing major features of the heart

pageData.text: The most important step in the heart dissection is placing the heart in the correct anatomical position. When the heart is in the anatomical position, it will be <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> (<button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button>) side up (facing you), and <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> (<button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button>) side down (against the absorbent pad). The left side of the heart will be on your right, and the right side of the heart will be on your left. Use the dissection mat for reference.

Note: In many drawings and photographs of correctly-positioned mammalian hearts, you will notice that the points to the left (your right). The apex may not be as easy to locate on your specimen because the preservation and packing processes often cause distortion. You can find the anterior side by looking for the T-shaped pulmonary trunk extending up and branching into the pulmonary arteries. You can confirm that you are looking at the anterior side of the heart by locating the . They will be oriented anteriorly, much like forwardpointing dog’s ears.

Locate and identify as many externally-visible structures as possible, using the dissection mat as a guide. Numbers in parentheses correspond to numbered structures on the heart dissection mat. In the following steps you are asked to identify and photograph a number of structures. Each photograph may have multiple structures pinned or presented. Take notes to keep track of which structures are presented in each picture.
  1. Use the forceps to grasp the tough, epicardial layer that adheres tightly to the heart.
  2. Approximate the locations of the right (20) and left (12) and right (21) and left (15) ventricles, using the (8) and interventricular sulcus (11) as guides.
  3. Note the atrial appendages (4) and the heart apex (3).
  4. Gently insert the blunt end of the probe into each of the following vessels: pulmonary (17) and pulmonary trunk (18), pulmonary vein, vena cava (22), (9), and (1).
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text:
Now you will open the heart along its in preparation for examining its internal structures.
  1. Position the heart for a longitudinal cut as shown on the front of the dissection mat. You will be looking down on the left , and the apex will be pointing toward you.
  2. Using the scalpel, start your incision just below the left atrium. Make a incision, cutting all the way to the (10).
  3. Continue the incision, slicing through the left ventricle until you have reached the apex.
  4. Cut through the left atrium until you have reached the start of the original incision.
  5. To complete the section, turn the heart over and cut from the apex through the right ventricle and right atrium. Now the heart should be cut completely in two along the frontal plane as shown on the back of the dissection mat.

Identify and photograph the internal structures of the heart, using the dissection mat as a reference. Take notes of which structures appear in each photograph so that you may label them later.
  1. Locate both atria, both , and all large blood vessels (previously identified in step 2d above). Photograph them again to show what they look like from the interior of the heart. As you examine the inner ventricular walls, notice the (23). Note the very thin, transparent layer of lining the heart chambers.
  2. Identify the (2). Also locate the , which is not labeled on the mat but lies between the right ventricle and the of the pulmonary trunk.
  3. Identify the bicuspid (5) and tricuspid (24) valves, as well as the chordae tendinae (7) and (16) attached to them. Inspect the valves and chordae tendinae, using a the hand lens if available, and compare their surfaces with those of the trabeculae carneae and the sectioned walls of the heart chambers. The trabeculae carneae, chamber walls, and papillary muscles are composed of tissue, whereas the valves and chordae tendinae are made up of connective tissue and endocardium.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.content: Figure 3. The structures, vessels, and blood flow of the heart

tableData.text: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with ventral
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with dorsal
Toward the back or spine; synonymous with posterior
Toward the belly or abdomen; synonymous with anterior
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross-sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.altText: Figure 4. A heart with the atrioventricular valves labeled.

pageData.content: Figure 5. Anatomical planes of a quadruped and a biped
pageData.altText: Figure 5. Drawing showing the midsagittal, transverse,and frontal anatomical planes on a quadruped, represented by a cat, and a biped, represented by a human.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.
You will start by setting up the work area and dissection the tools.
In Activity 1, you will need to locate and identify external structures of intact specimen. Then, divide the specimen in half along the frontal plane. Next, locate and identify the internal structures of specimen.

data.title: Anterior
data.content: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Aorta
data.content: The largest artery, receiving the systemic output of the heart

data.title: Aortic valve
data.content: Allows for blood from the left ventricle to be pumped up into the aorta

data.title: Apex
data.content: Pointed, lower end of the heart consisting of muscle from the left ventricle

data.title: Artery
data.content: Blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart

data.title: Atria
data.content: The upper two chambers of the heart, "receiving chambers", receive blood as it enters the heart

data.title: Atrial appendage
data.content: Ear-like flap made up of muscle from the atrium; also termed an auricular appendage or auricle

data.title: Atrioventricular valve
data.content: A valve between an atrium and ventricle of the heart

data.title: Atrium
data.content: One of the two upper chambers of the heart that receive blood; plural, atria

data.title: Base
data.content: Point of attachment for blood vessels entering and exiting the heart

data.title: Bicuspid valve (mitral valve)
data.content: A valve that only allows blood to flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle

data.title: Cardiac cycle
data.content: The rhythmic contraction and relaxation of the heart muscle

data.title: Cardiac muscle
data.content: An involuntary type of striated muscle tissue

data.title: Cardiac veins
data.content: Return Oxygen-poor blood from the walls of the heart to the pulmonary circula-tion

data.title: Chordae tendineae
data.content: Fibers that prevent the valves from opening during ventricular contraction

data.title: Coronary artery
data.content: Branches from the aorta as it leaves the heart

data.title: Coronary sulcus
data.content: Grove that passes around the heart and separates the ventricles below from the atria above and is also known as the atrioventricular groove; runs perpendicular to the interventricular groove

data.title: Deep
data.content: Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal

data.title: Dorsal
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Endocardium
data.content: Thin membrane lining the cavities of the heart

data.title: Epicardium
data.content: An outer connective tissue layer that encloses the heart

data.title: Frontal plane
data.content: Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: The dynamic equilibrium the body sustains when in good health

data.title: Inferior
data.content: Away from the head end of the biped body, or toward the lower part of a structure; below

data.title: Inferior vena cava
data.content: Receives blood returning to the heart from the lower body

data.title: Interatrial septum
data.content: Muscular wall between the right and left atria

data.title: Interventricular groove
data.content: Groove that runs perpendicular to the coronary sulcus and indicates the position of the interventricular septum

data.title: Interventricular septum
data.content: Muscular wall between the right and left ventricles

data.title: Midsagittal plane
data.content: Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane

data.title: Myocardium
data.content: The muscular layer of the heart wall

data.title: Papillary muscle
data.content: Found in the walls of the ventricles

data.title: Posterior
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Principle of complementarity of structure and function
data.content: Each anatomical structure always reflects its function and vice versa

data.title: Pulmonary circulation
data.content: Carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart through the capillaries in the lungs and then returns oxygenated blood to the heart

data.title: Pulmonary valve
data.content: A valve between the pulmonary artery and the right ventricle of the heart, prevents blood from flowing back into the right ventricle

data.title: Sagittal plane
data.content: Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions

data.title: Semilunar valve
data.content: Valve between the aorta and left ventricle, and between the pulmonary trunk and right ventricle; often called the aortic valve and pulmonary valve, respectively

data.title: Superficial
data.content: Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external

data.title: Superior
data.content: Toward the head end of the biped body, or the upper part of a structure; above

data.title: Superior vena cava
data.content: Receives blood from the upper body

data.title: Systemic circulation
data.content: Carries oxygenated blood to and returning deoxygenated blood from the tissues of the body

data.title: Trabeculae carneae
data.content: Ridges and folds on the walls of the ventricles

data.title: Transverse plane
data.content: Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections

data.title: Tricuspid valve
data.content: Consists of three thin flaps, sits between the heart's two right chambers

data.title: Vein
data.content: Blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart

data.title: Ventral
data.content: Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quad-rupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head

data.title: Ventricles
data.content: The lower two chambers of the heart, "pumping chambers", forcefully eject blood from the heart
